Topic.Title: Lake Michigan Credit Union Pay 3.00 Percent on a Checking Account

Message.Msg: You might want to consider the thought that those banks and credit unions that pay such high rates might just have to because they are having trouble getting enough deposits. That's a pretty high rate and not necessarily an indicator of a strong institution.

Topic.Title: IMO: Only Losers have Checking Accounts at Bank of America, N.A.

Message.Msg: Well, considering BAC and all the other mega banks continue to grow deposits without having to pay higher rates, while the credit unions have to keep raising their rates to try to attract more deposits sort of shows where the losers really are. You may get high rates for awhile, but watch out for those unannounced closures by the FCUA.

Topic.Title: Lake Michigan Credit Union Pay 3.00 Percent on a Checking Account

Message.Msg: The credit union makes the money to pay a customer 3 percent on a checking account when the customer uses his debit card for purchases at stores. The merchant pays a fee to his financial institution each and every time a credit card transaction is processed.

Topic.Title: IMO: Only Losers have Checking Accounts at Bank of America, N.A.

Message.Msg: Wrong! You are one lazy idiot who does not understand how a financial institution can pay a handsome dividend on a checking account. When one uses his debit card as a credit transaction at the store, the merchant pays a fee on each and every transaction processed. A portion of that fee goes back to the credit union.

Topic.Title: Short Clowns

Message.Msg: I remember years ago, when gold was around $500 an ounce, reading an article called "the bull market that nobody believes". The point was that people cannot recognize an emerging trend, they compare to prices a few years earlier and say "This can't go higher, it's already doubled, there's no money to be made" I see that often on here. It was a wave of extreme pessimism that drove this stock to $5. It's time to look at the chart for what it is. An uptrend. Gradual accumulation has been taking place in this issue, as the strong hands realize the worst is over. The company has been executing its plan in coordination with the FED for 4 years now. They sold off pieces, raised capital, reduced risk and long term debt expense. The new regulatory environment is a headwind but after this much time they've acclimated to it and are prepared to slog ahead. Does anyone seriously think they'll CCAR fail stress tests next year? That they won't continue to slim down preferreds and buy back common? I won't prognosticate where it'll trade next summer but it won't be in the 12's anymore and have moved up from there. This is what patient, value investing is all about.

Topic.Title: BENGHAZI. BUSH ASSASSINATED 3500 KIDS IN IRAQ, NOW THEY COMPLAINT FOR 1 AMBASSADOR

Message.Msg: I think Hillary had a part in that, too. Here's a direct quote from her: "In the four years since the inspectors left, intelligence reports show that Saddam Hussein has worked to rebuild his chemical and biological weapons stock, his missile delivery capability, and his nuclear program. He has also given aid, comfort, and sanctuary to terrorists, including Al Qaeda members... It is clear, however, that if left unchecked, Saddam Hussein will continue to increase his capacity to wage biological and chemical warfare, and will keep trying to develop nuclear weapons. Should he succeed in that endeavor, he could alter the political and security landscape of the Middle East, which as we know all too well, effects American security. This is a very difficult vote, this is probably the hardest decision I've ever had to make. Any vote that might lead to war should be hard, but I cast it with conviction." Hillary Clinton, US Senator from NY October 10, 2002 Your facts are not only selective, they are positively amesiatic. You should be thankful that you're only playing with half a deck. If you understood how impotent you sound, you would bury your head in shame.

Message.Msg: Hang on, let's hear from Billy Clinton: "People can quarrel with whether we should have more troops in Afghanistan or internationalize Iraq or whatever, but it is incontestable that on the day I left office, there were unaccounted for stocks of biological and chemical weapons." Former President Clinton During an interview on CNN's "Larry King Live" July 22, 2003 Note the date. If the war was Bush's fault, what exactly did Clinton do to eliminate those stockpiles? Nothing, you say? Correct. Case closed. You lefties on the socialist front have been revising history, and you are very poor writers. You forgot to extinguish every vestige of truth before you started publishing your pack of lies. As we pick apart every single little "fact" you throw out and show it to be false, will you then come to your senses and realize that you are the ones doing all of the lying and misleading? If you're incapable of intelligence, then I guess the answer to that will be a simple "no". Propaganda peddlers like you are a dime a dozen.

I applaud the President on focusing on this issue and on taking the lead to disarm Saddam Hussein. ... Others have talked about this threat that is posed by Saddam Hussein. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (Democrat, California) Addressing the US House of Representatives October 10, 2002 Congressional Record, p. H7777 You see, they rewrote history when Bush became too strong, too well-liked. Message.Title: Cartoonish GOP chickenhawks
Message.Msg: What happens when people with no military experience monday night quarterback military actions. Robert Gates. "Frankly I think my decisions would have been just as theirs were. Republican critics have said a Special Forces team or overflights by fighter aircraft based in Italy might have prevented the US losses or at least frightened off the attackers. Mr. Gates disagrees. Such actions, he said on CBSs Face the Nation Sunday, without knowing what the environment is, without knowing what the threat is, without having any intelligence in terms of what is actually going on the ground, would have been very dangerous." "It's sort of a cartoonish impression of military capabilities and military forces," Gates said, referring to morning-after analysis. "The one thing that our forces are noted for is planning and preparation before we send people in harm's way, and there just wasn't time to do that."
